The Hailstone Sequence and Collatz Conjecture

I came across the Hailstone Sequence problem earlier this week and decided to code it up. To me this is particulary interesting becuase we can write programs to calculate a particular sequence say for instance n = 10 but we can never prove the correctness of the Collatz conjecture . Even if we try a large number(which would probably take a significant amount of time). How many numbers have we not tried ? Well there is still infinitely more. This problem reminded me of some other mathematical mysteries. The Poincare conjecture solved by Dr. Grigori Perelman and Fermats Last Theoreom solved by Dr. Andrew Wiles. If you have an hour to waste this is a good video on the topic 



  import java.io.BufferedReader;
  import java.io.IOException;
  import java.io.InputStreamReader;


  public class HailStoneSequence {

	public static void main(String args[])
	{
		
		int n =ReadInput();
		
		
		while(n!=1)
		
		{
			if(checkForEven(n))
			{
				n =n/2;
			}
			else if(checkForOdd(n))
			{	
				n=(n*3)+1;
			}
			
			System.out.println(n);
		}
	}
	
	
	public static int ReadInput()
	
	{
		 System.out.println("Enter Value");
		 
		InputStreamReader input =  new InputStreamReader(System.in);
		BufferedReader reader = new BufferedReader(input);
		
		int  rin=0;
		try {
		  rin= Integer.parseInt(reader.readLine());
		}
		catch (IOException io)
		{
			System.out.println("Could not read value");
		}
		
		
		return rin;
		
		
	}
	
	
	public  static boolean checkForEven(int n)
	{
		if(n%2==0)
		{
			return true;
		}
		
		return false;
	}
	
	
	public static  boolean checkForOdd(int n)
	{
		 if(n%2==1)
		 {
			 return true; 
		 }
		 
		 return false;
    }

}
